thread.title: ‘Gainsborough’ Review: A Special Light Shone Out of Him

author: Maxwell Carter
title: ‘Gainsborough’ Review: A Special Light Shone Out of Him
text: To the casual museumgoer, Georgian portraiture conjures stiff, self-satisfied images of frilly costumes and gravity-defying hairdos. The art of Thomas Gainsborough (1727-88), however, like that of his contemporary Joshua Reynolds, was more than smooth finishes and frippery. At the 1782 Royal Academy exhibition, Reynolds singled out (and bought) Gainsborough’s decidedly earthy “Girl With Pigs.” In 1834, John Constable mooned over one of Gainsborough’s country views: “I now, even now think of it with tears in my eyes. No feeling of landscape ever equalled it.” Seventy years on, Walter Armstrong, the director of the National...
